This is what I screwed up when I responded to Jim's question earlier about how Uncontrolled showed up in the story.

I have an MC whose solution is Control. (She's a change character, and the OS Solution is also control.)

I've also imagined that she likes being in Control -- she's most comfortable when she's in control.

The thing that leaps to mind here is: if she's already always striving to be in control, can she have Control as a Solution?

What I'm wondering specifically is this: Nobody ever really has control. We want it, but it's always an illusion. So, could her solution actually be "try to have less control"? 

I think that's a restating of "give up the illusion of Control", btw.

I want to make sure that I'm not trying to solve "Uncontrolled" with ... "uncontrolled."

This is an area I would like to learn more about.  Often in the Dramatica Users Group podcast I have hear Chris say (and I have to be careful here because often what I think I hear isn't quite right) ...I often hear him say something about the goal of obtaining could be about losing. My question is, once you take the opposite side there how does that effect the rest of the issues and elements, etc.

So if a solution is control which is no control does that automatically make the problem not enough un-control?  And then do you need to take the opposite of the sympton and response?  like an algebra problem where anything you do to one side you have to do to the other side of the equation?

I think it depends on whether one defines an outcome of success or failure as control doesn't have to be an illusion.  

Most concerns dealing with control will stem from insecurities and fear.  Anyone cleaning to, asserting, or pursuing to control in this light will (most likely) end up with an outcome of failure because it is an illusion.  Beth in Ordinary People is a good example of this.

Where control is a positive outcome is when a person ultimately realizes the only control they have is how they respond to events outside of themselves.   This may result in an outcome of failure, but lead to a personal triumph where the character realizes the illusion but gains a greater understanding of themselves.

That being said, perhaps while control seems to be the problem - it's really perception with a solution of actuality?  A character perceives having more control over external things so they won't have to react (i.e. if person A would just do this instead of that, I wouldn't have to...).  

But in actuality, they realize they cannot control somebody else, only how they respond themselves to a situation (i.e., instead of trying to control person A to do this instead of that, they instead try to influence them by getting them to realize potential outcomes and their impacts).

When looking at the OS problem, it is not so much what the characters see as a problem so much as what is REALLY causing the problem.

Keep in mind that ALL of Dramatica's questions ask about what happens, not what could, should, would, or appears to happen.  

The OS Problem asks, "What is the source of conflict in the Overall Story throughline?"  Translated in to non-Dramatica-speak, "What causes conflict between all the characters, in one way or another and to varying degrees, when looking objectively at the efforts to achieve the story goal in the "big picture" part of the story."
